Helmut Doork.Action: Accepts coffee kindly from a small child offering help and smiles in response.
Sits alone in silence, appearing depressed and sad, withdrawn from others.
Takes coffee offered by the midget, shows a small smile of acknowledgment amid his sadness.
Lingering behind intentionally after all other clowns have left, showing hesitation or reluctance to join.
Carries Gustav's very long tails during the grand entrance, supporting him.
Accidentally causes both himself and Gustav to fall by not seeing the post.
Hangs back intentionally, delaying his exit from Clown Alley until last.
Carries Gustav's extremely long tails during the grand entrance.
Fails to notice the post while walking, resulting in falling and pulling down Gustav as well.
Accidentally causes a mishap but sincerely swears it was unintentional.
Submits silently and nods after being harshly reprimanded and threatened with humiliation.
Walks into the post, causing a comical fall and pulling down another clown.
Insists repeatedly that the mishap was an accident when confronted by Gustav and Schmidt.
Accepts punishment and demotion quietly without arguing.
Helmut cries privately, showing vulnerability and emotional depth.
Responds nastily to Ada's concern, showing irritability and unfriendliness.
Carries old, battered promotional materials indicating past glory but no current success; shows visible emotional distress and tears.
Engages in verbal sparring at bar, showing quick wit and assertiveness when telling Clause 'And you won't make a dime sticking your nose in other people's business.'
Drinks whiskey and beer shot in quick succession, indicating possible self-destructive coping mechanism.
Appears emotionally unstable and hostile to partner Ada when she expresses concern.
Blasts Ada's concern and accuses her of caring more about dinner than him.
Admits he can't trust anybody and shows vulnerability when speaking honestly about his feelings.
Responds to Ada's declaration of love by embracing her and apologizing sincerely.
Flops in chair, ignores tender words and pours another drink, showing withdrawal and emotional distancing.
Responds to Ada's encouragement by deciding to confront Schmidt and stand up for himself
Expresses feelings of emptiness and worthlessness, withdrawing inwardly
Walks away from Ada in anger before calming down to listen
Accepts Ada's encouragement and decides to confront Schmidt to stop further degradation, asserting his self-worth as a 'special clown'.
Initially displays self-pity and resignation to being powerless and 'nothing', doubting his talent and ability to fight back.
Tries to summon courage to call someone despite feeling foreign and lonely.
Listens outside the office tent, overhearing coworkers plot his departure and celebrate, feels discouraged but does not retaliate.
Drinks heavily at the bar, visibly beaten and shoddy, indicating internal struggle but no aggressive or hostile behavior.
Attempts to find courage to confront his situation, approaches Schmidt to negotiate.
Overhears the conversation agreeing to force him out without input or counteraction, becomes discouraged and retreats.
Withdraws emotionally and resorts to heavy drinking after facing defeat.
Complains about people taking things for granted and not understanding true loyalty; expresses personal loyalty but feels unappreciated.
Expresses contempt openly by slashing his throat gesture and angrily shouts at Hitler's photograph, calling him a fool.
Calls out the dishonesty and disloyalty of people like Herr Schmidt, criticizing Hitler indirectly and showing contempt for corrupt behavior.
Ranting drunkenly and aggressively in a public place despite the presence of dangerous men, puts himself at risk but seems to seek a kind of honesty or justice.
Does not warn others of the danger from the S.S. and Gestapo men who have arrived, leaving others frightened and isolated.
Physically and emotionally drained, yet attempts to communicate his message, suggesting sincerity and emotional investment.
Publicly denounces Hitler and criticizes the regime while heavily intoxicated and emotionally unsteady, showing poor situational awareness.
Attempts to distance himself physically from dangerous figures in the bar, albeit clumsily, indicating limited self-preservation instinct.
Continues to speak defiantly despite the presence of S.S. and Gestapo officers, showing lack of caution and strategic thinking.
Attempts to joke and engage the intimidating S.S. and Gestapo men with humor, trying to break tension.
Mimics and mocks the Gestapo men’s uniforms and seriousness, tries to get them to laugh.
Becomes hysterical laughing at his own joke, showing vulnerability and a desire for connection.
Mocks the S.S. and Gestapo men by pointing out their obvious uniforms and suggesting they dress plainly to avoid detection.
Behaves erratically by staggering and mumbling while confronting intimidating men, losing some control of the situation.
Attempts to use humor to defuse a tense situation and engages the men to get a reaction, showing social insight.
Fails to read the room accurately as the men do not respond as expected to his humor, indicating a misjudgment.
Dips his comb in a man's beer and uses brown jam to mockingly create a mustache, then loudly shouts 'Heil me!' and collapses on the floor.
Stands frightened and unsure in the doorway, displays a sick, little-boy smile hoping to endear himself to Reicher.
Walks into a tense room frightened and unsure, stands quietly and waits under intimidating scrutiny.
Attempts to endear himself to Reicher with a sick, little-boy smile during a stressful interrogation.
Attempts to impress Reicher by boasting about his past achievements as a premier clown.
Shows nervousness and meekness when confronted and demeaned by Reicher.
Admits softly and sincerely that he cannot make anything funny from his current situation.
Attempts to assert his past competence and importance with confidence, claiming to be the Premier Clown who performed for royalty.
Quickly loses composure when confronted with the harsh reality of his current insignificance, showing meekness and despair.
Fails to maintain confidence or control in conversation with Lt. Reicher, allowing his self-image to be shattered easily.
Momentarily forgets danger and his position, revealing ego and past pride.
Admits he was drunk and responsible for his disrespectful actions, tries to explain without hostility
Claims to be a loyal German and more loyal than most but fails to back it up and tries to avoid naming others
Sweats and tries desperately to avoid providing names when pressured
Claims drunkenness to excuse his actions and avoid responsibility.
Attempts to assert loyalty but fails to convincingly support his claim under pressure.
Hesitates and fails to provide names when pressed, showing poor preparedness and weak defense.
Sweats and shows visible signs of stress and uncertainty under interrogation.
Refuses to admit responsibility, avoids answer under intimidation.
Unable to provide a clear explanation or take responsibility when questioned; repeatedly says 'I don't know' under pressure.
Walks with a slow rhythm, head down, embarrassed and shattered while being moved like a broken prisoner.
Walks slowly with head down, embarrassed and shattered, showing no resistance or engagement with his situation.
Follows the group of broken men without asserting control or leadership, lacking visible confidence or skill.
Swirls the spoon in the slop instead of eating, showing possible lack of engagement or resistance to nourishment.
Bites down on the spoon and refuses to open his mouth despite the Guard's pressure.
Allows himself to be forcibly fed and humiliated without retaliating or escaping.
Refuses to kill the guard despite being provoked and holding a knife, showing restraint and self-control.
Pleads politely for the guard to stop feeding him when he is overwhelmed, indicating a sincere attempt to communicate his needs calmly.
Does not retaliate verbally or physically against the guard's insults and provocations, instead internalizing his anguish.
Holds the knife in a stabbing style, considers killing the guard, but restrains himself for strategic reasons.
Allows himself to be force-fed excessively by the guard, resulting in a physical mess and loss of control.

Shows intense inner conflict, considers violence but restrains himself to protect his own chance of release; reacts with visible emotional pain and sadness, leaves the mess hall alone and crestfallen.
Contemplates stabbing the guard with a knife but refrains in order to avoid jeopardizing his imminent release.
Shows visible emotional distress and withdraws in a defeated manner after the guard mocks him and the others leave him alone in the mess hall.
Prays silently, showing vulnerability and fear.
Startled and recoils when approached by Keltner, showing distrust or fear of others.
Walks back and forth nervously like a caged lion, appears angry, hurt, sad, and generally out of sorts, unable to hear Keltner approaching.
Stops and lays his head against the barracks wall, muttering a prayer, showing vulnerability but no clear skill or confidence.
Speaks optimistically about help from a guard, expressing hope and sharing this with Keltner.
Shows excitement and care when discussing the form, indicating sincerity and trust in the process.
Ignores Keltner's gentle invitation to watch the birds and remains absorbed in his papers, oblivious to the shared moment.
Responds to Keltner's repeated calls after initially being distracted, showing some attentiveness.
Engages in a thoughtful conversation about religion prompted by Keltner, showing some openness and receptiveness.
Expresses concern that birds could be eaten here, implying care for their safety.
Goes back to studying his papers without further engagement when others show compassion.
Makes a practical and somewhat grim observation about the birds potentially being eaten, showing awareness of surroundings but not optimism.
Returns to studying his papers calmly after the conversation, indicating focus and persistence.
Writes on an old piece of paper with a scruffy pencil, demonstrates resourcefulness and attention to detail even in poor conditions.
Notices and acknowledges Keltner's sprouting potato despite being preoccupied with his own concerns.
Accepts Keltner's gesture of holding his hand as Keltner places the potato on the window sill.
Appears detached or distracted when responding to Keltner, focusing on bureaucratic details rather than the hopeful symbol Keltner presents.
Sees that Keltner has help and decides to back off, withdrawing into his corner absorbed in his own pain and fantasy.
Runs over anxiously to the guard before he exits to remind him about the papers.

Sees that Keltner has help so he decides to back off and hide in his little corner with his pencil and scrap of paper... totally involved with his own pain and his undying fantasy about his ultimate release
Runs over to catch the guard before he makes his exit to remind him about the papers
Anxiously tries to get the guard to bring important papers, shows concern about bothering the guard again, asks Keltner to remind the guard on his behalf.
Anxiously tries to catch the guard to get papers but is unsuccessful and shows despair afterward.
Recognizes that asking the guard repeatedly would annoy him and instead asks Keltner to remind the guard, showing some social awareness and strategic thinking.
Remarks on the sick potato plant with light humor and shares laughter with others.
Laughs at Keltner's claim to own the plant and jests about knitting, mocking him.
No direct actions or statements from Helmut Doork in the excerpt; passive or absent behavior, no demonstration of skill or confidence.
Initially avoids confrontation and returns to studying, showing reluctance to engage with the bully.
Notices Keltner's disappointment and decides to intervene by confronting Galt to defend Keltner.
Firmly demands Galt to give back the plant and leave Keltner alone, standing up against bullying.
Initially avoids confrontation by focusing on studying, showing reluctance to get involved.
Recognizes Keltner's disappointment and decides to intervene by confronting Galt directly and standing up to the bully.
Uses firm and clear verbal assertiveness to de-escalate potential conflict and defend Keltner.
Firmly defends Keltner by telling others to leave him alone and not pick on him.
Physically attacked and injured while protecting another.
Stands up firmly to defend Keltner and demands the others to leave him alone.
Gets hit hard by Galt and falls half unconscious, not successfully defending himself physically.
Takes a moral stand that provokes others and leads to his own injury, showing a lack of consideration for his own physical safety.
Keltner leans down and picks Helmut up and helps him onto his bunk, puts the plant on his own bunk.
Allows Keltner to clean his bloody mouth without protest, though responds rudely ('nice and STUPID!') and then turns away, rejecting kindness.
Sneaks out cautiously to approach the Guard’s shack at night, acting meek and frightened.
Sneaks out cautiously after checking the area is clear; moves stealthily like a prisoner avoiding detection.
Carefully approaches the Guard's shack and knocks on the door instead of barging in.
Appears meek and frightened in front of the Guard; fails to assert himself confidently.
Responds to the Guard's questions by shaking his head 'no' meekly, showing a lack of confidence or persuasive skill.
Screams in frustration due to child-like treatment and hunger.
Turns red and yells at guard to shut his mouth to answer questions.
Bows head meekly and apologizes for raising his voice, showing submission and regret.
Whispers 'I'm sorry' after being hit and threatened, showing submissiveness and no retaliation.
Attempts to answer the Guard's questions but becomes frustrated and raises his voice.
Bows his head in fear and apologizes meekly after being intimidated by the Guard.
Endures physical abuse silently and allows Keltner to help him to his bunk, showing vulnerability and reliance on others.
Remains stonefaced and erect despite guard's cruelty, indicating a lack of open emotional response or friendliness in this moment.
Becomes erect and stonefaced at the guard's words, showing internal resolve despite physical weakness.
Physically unable to resist or escape, allowing himself to be dragged and beaten without retaliating.
Slowly gets up in pain, tries to reach his bunk, and accepts help from Keltner, demonstrating some ability to persevere and navigate difficult circumstances.
Grimly refuses help and pushes Keltner away, showing pain but rejecting kindness.
Ignores advice to not irritate the guard and acts against warnings.
Refuses to engage or explain when confronted, gritting teeth and telling others to leave him alone.
Does not wake up on time, still asleep when others are moving out, requiring a guard to intervene.
Remains asleep while others are inspected, unaware and vulnerable in cold barracks.
Blows warm air into socks to warm them before putting them on.
Uses ingenuity to heat water for washing despite harsh conditions, and tries to care for his hygiene and appearance.
Exits the toilet carefully after enduring painful cold and heat, suggests self-care under duress.
Brags to new prisoners about turning down an opportunity to join the Ringling Brothers circus, emphasizing loyalty to his 'own people' and pride in being German.
Brags confidently about negotiating with Mr. Ringling and refusing to leave Germany for personal/cultural reasons.
Surrounds himself by an audience and seeks validation through boasting rather than demonstrating actual achievements or skills.
Nods with studied humility when praised about his clown act, showing modesty.
Eats up the prisoners' praise and engages warmly with them, sharing about the clown faces and make-up process.
Panicingly tries to keep the prisoners’ attention from breaking up, pleading emotionally for more time to share stories.
Nods with studied humility, managing to conceal that he doesn't remember the clown he supposedly portrayed.
Eats up the praise from prisoners, showing he enjoys flattering attention.
Explains thoughtfully to prisoners that clown makeup comes from years of trial and error.
Panics and emotionally begs prisoners to listen when they begin to leave, showing lack of composure.
Attempts to engage others by sharing interesting clown trivia, but is ignored and left isolated.
Feels despair and displays a broken, sad demeanor when rejected by the group.
Considers joining the group activity but physically cannot bring himself to participate, showing vulnerability.
Attempts to engage others by sharing interesting facts and trying to participate in the group activity.
Fails to get attention or connect with others; physically unable to join group, showing limpness and despair.
Watches the playful belly-dancing with a look of disgust and turns away, focusing on his papers instead.
Turns away from the comedic dance with a look of disgust and diligently returns to work on his papers and calculations.
Refuses to engage in lighthearted activities or entertain the group despite prompting.
Expresses willingness to help but explains his limitations without hostility.
Does not resist or escalate bullying, stays composed when challenged by Galt.
Explains calmly why he cannot perform without proper props or makeup, demonstrating awareness of his craft's requirements.
Initially prepares to engage by swinging legs ready to jump down but stops when reminded of limitations, showing self-control and situational awareness.
Avoids immediate conflict or emotional reaction to intimidation attempts by Galt, maintaining composure.
Insists he needs proper props and costume to perform, showing frustration but trying to be truthful.
Appears confused and unable to recall his previous lies, which suggests internal conflict rather than deceitful friendliness.
Expresses frustration and confusion, unable to recall simple parts of his past act and demands props to perform.
Attempts to set boundaries by stating he cannot perform without proper equipment and props.
Refuses to perform a humiliating act, verbally lashes out at Keltner's suggestion.
Expresses a need to avoid certain actions despite group pressure.
Helmut is being violently choked and stomped by the men; he fights to breathe and tries to resist despite being overpowered.
Despite being violently choked and stomped on, he struggles and kicks his legs, attempting to resist.
Lies on the floor, gasping for air after being subdued, shows physical vulnerability and momentary incapacitation.
Gets up dizzily when ordered by the guard, showing some ability to obey and gather himself after assault.
Attempts to stop the guard to ask about his release forms, showing initiative and vulnerability.
Whispers to Keltner about being picked on, expressing hurt and sincerity.
Does not retaliate or escalate conflict after being physically grabbed and turned away by Keltner.
Admits doubt about others believing his identity as a clown, shows vulnerability by whispering to Keltner and expressing pain when confronted.
Questions if he should have performed for the men, shows self-doubt about his clown persona.
Leans over to whisper to Keltner and openly confronts his doubts, demonstrating some self-awareness.
Stares at Keltner, feeling pain but avoids challenging the uncomfortable truth, indicating hesitance and lack of courage in that moment.
Expresses confusion and concern about the new barbed wire fence separating prisoners from women and children, questioning its purpose.
Expresses confusion and asks 'What does it mean? What do they need a fence for?'
Does not intervene or show sympathy toward prisoners despite their distress; enforces harsh punishment by canceling all rations for 48 hours under guise of 'correcting' their energy levels.
Runs after the guard when prisoners face ration cuts despite others' anger and hopelessness.
Appears undecided and hesitant initially, showing internal conflict.
Approaches guard obsequiously, possibly showing insincerity or fear.
Helmut tries to advocate for himself by asking the guard about promised forms but is met with silence; he walks away crushed and head down.
Helmut faces hostility from fellow prisoners accusing him of making deals and being responsible for their lack of food, but he remains silent and tries to explain calmly.
Tries to advocate for himself by asking the guard about special forms for Gestapo review, showing initiative to improve his situation.
Stops himself from speaking further after guard denies him, showing some self-restraint or awareness.
Faces a hostile group warily and remains silent rather than escalating conflict, indicating cautiousness.
Fails to secure promised paperwork from the guard, resulting in worsening situation and alienation from peers.
Admonishes his peers explaining the situation calmly, indicating ability to communicate under pressure.
Does not appear to have planned an effective strategy to gain support or secure resources, ending up isolated and criticized.
Holds up his hands to quiet the men, hoping to stall performing and preserve his reputation.
Attempts to stall the men from demanding a performance by holding up his hands to quiet them, trying to preserve his reputation as a great clown.
Attempts to preserve dignity and offer a performance despite pressure and fear.
Holds up hands to quiet men, hoping to stall violence and control situation.
Shows fear and looks for help but remains engaged with the men.
Holds up his hands to quiet the men, hoping to stall and preserve his reputation as a great clown.
Grandly announces he will perform a real show and asks for time to prepare props and a costume.
Draws himself up proudly and tries to move forward despite the pressure and threats from the men.
Strains to look beyond the men for help and attempts to scream for the guard, showing fear but also a desire to seek assistance.
Tries earnestly to entertain the prisoners despite fear and pressure, attempts physical comedy to make them laugh.
Does not give up or complain openly despite being threatened and humiliated.
Cannot elicit any positive response from the prisoners and is visibly frightened and humiliated.
Nods in reluctant agreement to perform under duress from violent men.
Nods to comply when threatened but fails to perform a convincing act despite frantic effort.
Attempts multiple clown routines to entertain men despite fear and pressure.
Insists he is a clown and pleads for a chance despite being ridiculed and physically humiliated.
Tries to perform a handstand despite slippery mud but fails and falls ignominiously.
Repeatedly insists he is a clown and pleads for a chance despite negative reactions.
Remains determined after failure, claims he can do it again.
Plays in the mud to amuse a timid child despite uncertain initial reactions.
Bows stiffly to the boy, showing a sincere attempt at connection.
Seeks validation by looking towards barracks mates but shows disappointment when alone.
Observes the boy laughing and deliberately uses mud to create a clown mask on his face to entertain the child.
Attempts a handstand and allows himself to fall deliberately to amuse the child, showing awareness of his actions and audience.
Looks disappointed when no one from his barracks is watching, showing insecurity and a need for validation.
Performs a clown act to entertain children, bows deeply as tribute to their appreciation, smiles and continues engaging despite tears.
Gratefully acknowledges the extra food given by the messman with a smile.
Secretly pockets a piece of bread and hides that he has eaten some mush, indicating cautious self-preservation.
Carefully and cleverly hides part of his bread by smoothing the mush to appear untouched, showing resourcefulness and cautious planning to secure extra food.
Moves with difficulty, 'as if having trouble controlling his own feet,' suggesting physical weakness or poor control but not necessarily reflecting on competence.
Offers his bowl of bread and mush to the Big Prisoner despite his own hunger.
Watches the Big Prisoner eat, showing empathy and patience.
Reminds the Big Prisoner not to forget his bowl after eating.
Moves off quietly after sharing food, not demanding anything in return.
Offers his own meager food to the Big Prisoner, maintaining a positive demeanor despite evident hunger.
Walks awkwardly wearing shoes many sizes too large and cut open, but claims they are 'perfect' to the Big Prisoner, suggesting an attempt to maintain morale or optimism.
Reminds the Big Prisoner to return the bowl, showing attentiveness to small practical details.
Fixes the Big Prisoner's shoes in a way that serves the act but could cause discomfort, and promises to repair them properly later.
Gives the Big Prisoner a piece of bread, who then self-consciously returns it; Helmut smiles to express thanks.
Modifies the Big Prisoner's shoes for a performance act despite risk of damage and promises to repair them later.
Promises to fix the shoes before returning them, demonstrating some accountability.
Quickly leaves after the interaction, possibly indicating awareness and focus.
Gives the Big Prisoner a piece of bread and accepts it back with a thankful smile, showing social awareness and gratitude.
Smiles gratefully when catching the bread, lopes jauntily among prisoners, unaware but well-liked as many smile and nod toward him
Catches the piece of bread and smiles to express thanks.
Lopes off toward his barracks jauntily, unaware of others' positive gestures.
Sheepishly admits he feared punishment, shares bread given by the Big Prisoner, and shows willingness to improve the act for others' benefit.
Tears up Franz's coat causing frustration but insists on using it for the act because it's the only fitting one.
Remains silent and does not retaliate during hateful and provocative insults from Galt and Uhlmann, focusing instead on the coat he wants.
Firmly insists on keeping the clown costume despite others' objections, explaining it's his trademark and promising to be careful.
Remains silent and focused on the coat during confrontation and insults, not engaging or escalating conflict.
Accepts coat in a gracious manner, nodding as if receiving homage.
Struts away with dignity in big shoes, focusing on his own presence rather than others.
Is deep in thought, reflecting on being laughed at not just by children but adults too.
Shows awareness that clowns must entertain adults as well as children, indicating understanding of audience needs.
Wants to create new, genuinely funny material and cares about entertaining children specifically.
Expresses hope to entertain at other camps despite the grim circumstances.
Gets annoyed when confronted with a contradiction about who his audience really is.
Confidently claims he has new, funny material and plans to debut it.
Expresses unrealistic hopes about getting permission to entertain in other camps without concrete action.
Shows enthusiasm and initiative by practicing a new act and asking Keltner to watch it.
Contradicts himself about whether his clowning is meant for adults or children, indicating a lack of clear understanding.
Performs as a clown for the children behind the barbed wire fence, eliciting their laughter and joy despite the hostile environment.
Despite claiming to theorize about clowning for adults, he chooses to focus on the children, showing his genuine concern for their happiness.
Performs a playful clown act, trying repeatedly to sweep dirt onto cardboard, showing persistence and humor that delights children.
Attempts to wear too-small jacket, performs a playful soldier act, enduring embarrassment while making children laugh.
Engages in self-deprecating physical comedy despite personal discomfort and embarrassment, eliciting laughter and smiles from both children and prisoners.
Tries to button a too-small jacket, awkwardly attempts to march and snap to attention, causing the coat to pop open and knocking himself down while saluting, resulting in laughter from his audience.
Does not speak up or intervene when hearing laughter interrupting an important briefing about the shipment of prisoners.
Listens to orders carefully and shows awareness of plans regarding prisoner shipment and treatment.
Performs a show for the children in the prison camp.
Bows to applauding youngsters, engages in clown routine for children.
Stops performance instantly when guard orders to clear out children.
Bows to applauding youngsters, maintaining composure during an interrupted performance.
Stops, startled when the guard announces the show is over, showing some confusion or hesitation.
Speaks softly to the children, encouraging them to leave gently and saying goodbye warmly.
Expresses confusion and mild protest when ordered to stop the shows that make the children laugh.
Complies without resistance when taken away by the guard, showing no defiance or bitterness.
Speaks softly and calmly to the children to get them to comply without causing panic.
Continues to encourage the children as they reluctantly move away, maintaining control of the situation.
Shows confusion and lack of understanding when told the show is permanently cancelled; fails to immediately grasp the seriousness of the new order.
Tries to explain he wasn't mixing with the Jewish children, showing concern and confusion about the prohibition.
Accepts the guard's order dejectedly and shuffles off without resistance.
Attempts to explain himself to the guard, showing a willingness to communicate and clarify his intentions.
Obeys the guard's order reluctantly and dejectedly shuffles away without resistance or alternative action.
Expresses confusion and questions why laughter should be prohibited, showing some lack of understanding of the power dynamics at play.
Quickly retreats back into the barrack after being seen by the children watching him
Admits to Keltner his insecurity and emotional pain about the children staring at him
Attempts to share a small act of kindness/connection by showing Keltner he sewed a button on someone's coat
Sews a button on Franz's coat and gently pats the coat before folding it carefully.
Expresses desire to make the children laugh and worries about their wellbeing in prison.
Wishes the children could be taken out of prison and struggles emotionally with thinking about them.
Considers talking to the Commandant to make him understand, but realizes it is useless.
Expresses feeling of betrayal by children who now stare at him coldly.
Thinks of talking directly to children to explain himself and regain their understanding.
Pleads to talk to the children and expresses that he wishes he could forget them but can't, showing emotional concern and a refusal to turn his back on the children.
Acknowledges he cannot perform anymore yet wants to do something for the children so they don't think he has turned against them.
Pleading to talk to the children despite the risk; acknowledges the danger but insists on doing something for the children.
Admits uncertainty about his own motives and his inability to perform anymore, showing self-awareness but indecision.
Looks to Keltner for help and approval, indicating some dependence and lack of full confidence.
Grins broadly in response to Keltner's supportive gesture (arm around shoulder).
Initially resists involving others, telling Keltner there's no reason for him to get involved.
Nods obediently to Keltner's instructions and agrees to keep the children quiet to avoid trouble.
Moves quietly and unobtrusively to support the prisoners’ plan and protect the children.
Children react warmly to Helmut, pressing closer and greeting him; he does not reject or discourage them.
Nods and acknowledges instructions from Keltner, then moves stealthily across the yard trying to blend in while maintaining awareness.
Keeps the children quiet and prevents trouble as instructed, showing self-control and situational awareness.
Does not speak up or question the plan, but follows orders precisely, indicating reliable execution of assigned tasks.
Consoles a crying boy who is injured, removes his own ascot to help bandage the wound, tries to cheer him up by imitating a duck and quacking.
Comforts a crying child with a hurt arm and tries to bandage it with his ascot, attempting to make the child feel better.
Looks around frantically for help but finds none before improvising with his scarf.
Uses playful behavior (duck imitation) to calm the crying child, succeeding in stopping the crying briefly.
Makes progress soothing the crying child by playful, silly behavior, and smiles reassuringly at him.
Attempts to comfort the group of foreign, frightened children by telling them there is nothing to be afraid of, despite their lack of understanding.
Shows hesitation and fear but remains with the children, trying to engage and soothe them.
Calms a crying child skillfully using physical humor and gentle behavior, adapting actions to the child's reactions.
Attempts to communicate reassurance to a group of fearful children who do not respond due to language barriers, showing awareness but limited success.
Notices time constraints and hesitates, showing uncertainty about how long he can engage, indicating some lack of confidence in managing priorities.
Responds promptly to a subtle call to hurry, demonstrating situational awareness and ability to shift focus as needed.
Performs pantomime antics to entertain children, eliciting laughter and smiles.
Ignores potential danger from guards despite their watchful attention, prioritizing children's joy.
Pantomimes sewing his thumb to his jacket and reacts with embarrassment, engaging children and making them laugh.
Holds up his hands to try to silence the children while grinning and clearly enjoying their laughter, but children continue laughing and ignore his request.
Throws caution away and attempts a handspring, falls but recovers with a grin, continuing to entertain the children.
Performs joyfully and enthusiastically for the children despite falling repeatedly; tries to maintain a playful facade by pretending to slip
Is oblivious to the approaching guards and danger while performing, showing focus on the children rather than self-preservation
Turns away from the beating, hides under jacket, and performs clown antics to distract frightened children.
Engages in a frenzied 'Clap Dance' amid violence, incongruous behavior that captivates and calms the children.
Allows himself to be seized and dragged away by guards, showing no resistance in order to protect the children.
Waves back at the children, makes a funny face and moves his feet in something approaching a dance step while being dragged away.
No direct actions or statements in this excerpt indicating warmth; similarly, no friendly or trustworthy behavior observed.
Not present or mentioned in this excerpt, no actions or statements attributable to him.
Applies makeup quietly on the way back from solitary, shows no resistance or complaint despite harsh treatment.
Makes a small, lighthearted comment about wishing for big shoes to Scharff during a tense, silent ride.
Applies makeup carefully despite physical and emotional strain, maintaining composure under difficult circumstances.
Experiences effects of beating and solitary confinement that may impair his abilities, indicating physical and mental vulnerability.
Expresses concern that prison is no place for children and calls it a mistake.
Quotes Johann Keltner saying those who wage war on children commit a heinous crime deserving even the devil's damnation.
Shows vanity and arrogance when preparing clown makeup, focusing on elegance and appearance.
Speaks confidently about the Commandant personally requesting a review of his case, interpreting it optimistically.
Carefully inspects his makeup and adjusts it thoughtfully, showing attention to detail.
Expresses a personal belief that prison is no place for children and that moving them is a good idea.
References a moral statement made by Johann Keltner regarding men who wage war on children, showing reflective thinking.
Appears somewhat arrogant when boasting about the Commandant’s request, which may indicate overconfidence but not incompetence.
Looks toward the partially open boxcar door from which children can be heard crying, silently acknowledging their distress.
Helmut quickly gets out of the car and moves over to Scharff when called.
Helmut looks toward the partially open door and states, 'They're crying...'
Puts on a wide grin before looking inside the boxcar, then his eyes cease to smile when he sees the crying children.
Nods to Scharff and agrees to keep the children quiet despite evident distress.
Stiffens under Scharff's hand on his shoulder, indicating discomfort or fear.
Nods to Scharff's order and approaches the boxcar with a forced grin, then carefully peers inside, showing cautiousness and awareness of the situation.
Seems shocked and uncertain when questioning about how long the children have been there, indicating momentary emotional disturbance.
Follows instructions to deliver bread and keep the children quiet, agreeing to Scharff’s demand without hesitation.
Greets children gently, acknowledges their hiding place, and returns a hug warmly.
Reassures a crying boy by saying 'there's nothing to cry about' and promises fun.
Brings a gift for the children and instructs them patiently to wait before opening it.
Allows children to help him climb into the car, accepting their physical support positively.
Calmly restores order after a chaotic reunion by speaking gently and breaking the stunned silence.
Comfortingly hugs the boy who expresses distress and tries to reassure the children.
Gives a gift to the children and instructs them clearly on how to handle it, showing foresight and control.
Physically struggles to get into the car but coordinates with the children to get helped inside, demonstrating determination and collaboration.
Engages the children with playful gestures and humor, encouraging them to imitate his Jack-in-the-box movements, creating laughter and shared joy.
Responds to the children’s adoration by embracing them and trying to protect them, showing care and affection.
Notices the sudden shift to solemn silence among the children and immediately attempts to uplift their spirits by diverting their attention to food and a game.
Shares his limited food (black bread) with the children, eating with them to encourage and comfort.
Engages the children with playful and inclusive behavior, gets them to imitate him and follow instructions, effectively regains their attention and manages their hunger.
Kneels beside the little girl, comforts her with a gentle story about her mother being with her in her heart, engages all children to close their eyes and imagine their parents with them.
Notices the return of sadness and quickly brightens to lift the children's spirits by suggesting they share their names to create connection.
Carefully traces letters on boy's head to help learn names, engages warmly with children, winks and encourages playful interaction.
Takes initiative to learn everyone's names and creates a playful method to remember them by 'writing' their names on their heads with a pencil eraser end.
Uses a confident and gentle approach to engage children, earning their trust and attention.
Displays awareness of group dynamics and encourages interaction between children.
Gently plants a kiss on the child's cheek and encourages naming the children and their dolls to help them feel recognized and cared for.
Interacts warmly and playfully with children despite the language barrier, using gestures and patience.
Shows mock dismay at the doll's name 'Frederika' and humorously comments on the doll's head size, engaging the children in light-hearted play.
Effectively communicates despite language barrier, uses gesture and naming to connect with children.
Shows playful problem-solving by assessing if the doll's head is large enough to fit the name.
Suggests shortening Frederika to Freda, showing gentle compromise with the child.
Writes on the doll's head and makes children laugh delightedly.
Sings softly to children, who cuddle close to him while near sleep.
Accepts harmonica from Sergeant Hoffman carefully, promising not to tell the Lieutenant.
Requests a light to comfort the children as it gets dark, showing concern for their fear.
Nods understandingly to Sergeant Hoffman's refusal and justifies his situation, demonstrating empathy and tolerance.
Attempts to soothe a frightened and crying child by speaking gently and trying to comfort her physically.
Asks the guard for a light subtly despite risk, showing awareness of authority and restrictions.
Understands and sympathizes with Hoffman's position and limitations; communicates non-confrontationally.
Tries to play a soft tune on the harmonica despite limited skill, creating comfort for the children.
Responds quickly and gently to a frightened child, attempting to comfort her despite her withdrawal.

Uses a harmonica tune to soothe a crying child who initially shrinks from his comfort, then playfully engages her by making a funny face and encouraging her to touch his make-up, leading to shared laughter and smiles.
Picks up the child and pretends to dance with her, eliciting outright laughter and affection, ending with a mutual cheek kiss and appreciative gesture.
Responds to the older girl's question about children by looking at the children around and saying 'I do now' with a sad smile, implying he considers these children as his own.
Gives Sergeant Hoffman a look of deep gratitude after receiving instructions about the train and lighting the lantern inside the boxcar.
Attempts to comfort frightened children inside the moving boxcar with forced gaiety.
Listens carefully to Sergeant Hoffman and acknowledges the urgency of the train's arrival.
Looks down from the boxcar door, appears confused but manages to communicate with Hoffman and the children.
Attempts to reassure frightened children with forced gaiety despite uncertainty of the situation.
Reassures children about the train ride and tries to comfort them despite his own anxiety.
Unable to go with children on the train ride, causing their insecurity and sadness but promises to see them soon.
Feels terrible discomfort and near tears witnessing children’s pleading, showing empathy.
Maintains control and says goodbye gently despite emotional turmoil.
Backs away from children and does not protest or fight for their safety.
Approaches the crying children and tries to understand their distress despite his own discomfort and desire to leave.
Speaks pointedly to the girl with the accusing look, showing frustration and withdrawing slightly from the children's emotions.
Glances around to confirm the train isn't moving before approaching the children, showing situational awareness and cautiousness.
Engages the children in conversation to understand why the boy is crying, demonstrating attempts at communication and problem-solving.
Fails to clarify the language barrier effectively, leading to confusion over the boy's birthday and the children's explanations.
Appears helpless and unable to resolve the emotional distress of the children, showing indecision and emotional discomfort.
Tries to get off the train but is restrained by emotional and social cues (accusing looks), indicating lack of assertiveness or clarity in prioritization.
Softens, recalls his own birthday disappointment, wishes boy happy birthday, and gives him a harmonica with flourish.
Supports the little girl by affirming the value of the doll gift despite gender norms; places the doll hands together encouraging sharing.
Looks apprehensively toward the door, aware of possible danger but still chooses to engage warmly with the children.
Finds the harmonica with a flourish to give as a present, creatively solving the problem of a birthday gift.
Comforts the girl hurt by the German boy's scoff, skillfully mediating and promoting sharing despite social norms.
Looks towards the door apprehensively but chooses to stay calm and maintain focus under pressure.
Softens and shows wonder and empathy when recalling his own birthday disappointment, demonstrating emotional intelligence but some vulnerability.
Engages children in a playful game, borrows harmonica politely, reassures children, encourages them with a fun train imitation.
Assesses the situation carefully by looking outside to gauge available time before acting.
Plans and initiates an engaging activity to entertain the children, showing situational awareness and leadership.
Negotiates with the boy for the harmonica using nonverbal communication and reassurance to gain cooperation.
Keeps the children's attention and maintains order by instructing them to line up and hold each other to create a 'train'.
Demonstrates confidence and creativity by mimicking a train with the harmonica and leading the children in a playful activity.
Reacting quickly and calling 'WAIT!' when he hears the door slam, showing alertness and prompt response.
Pounds on the locked door, shouting to be let out, showing desperation and fear.
Manages his fear and smiles at the children, reassuring them despite his own fright.
Switches on the lantern to illuminate all the children, showing care and protection.
Responds to a child's suggestion to play with a stunned nod then plays the harmonica, engaging the children in a friendly manner.
Finds the door locked and pounds on it, tries to escape but eventually controls his fear and comforts the children with a smile and play.
Lies on his side with one arm thrown protectively over the little Czech girl, Inga, and Willie; children are huddled close to him for comfort and warmth.
Protectively shields children, creating a comforting environment among them despite harsh conditions.
Tries to calm children who are startled by the train stopping, answers their questions sincerely with 'I don't know.'
Shows care and responsibility by mentioning he was taking care of the children and accidentally got locked in with them.
Sits up and tries to get his bearings quickly after the train stops.
Responds honestly and calmly to the guards' questioning, explaining he was with the children and accidentally locked in.
Initially does not have clear knowledge of their location or situation, answers 'I don't know' when asked by children.
Attempts to rise and move towards the door but is stopped abruptly by the guard.
Helps children up into the truck gently, reassures them he will be with them soon, waves goodbye to them.
Realizes he's in trouble but calmly states his name without panicking.
Quickly organizes frightened children, helping them to their feet and encouraging them to move.
Attempts to stay with the children despite being ordered not to, showing concern but also understanding the situation's limits.
Fails to physically prevent children from being moved or mistreated, showing limited control over the situation.
Looks back at the children and waves goodbye to them as they march off reluctantly.
Expresses disappointment and hope that the children were going to a better place, showing a concern for their wellbeing.
Stares out the barred window in the prison cell with a sense of unease and stiffness as footsteps approach.
Does not overtly challenge or resist Captain Runkel's authority or statements, remaining uneasy but silent.
Looks back at the children and waves to them, showing some care and awareness of their situation.
Expresses disappointment that the children are just going to another prison, indicating some lack of understanding or naive expectations about the situation.
Stops pacing and looks out the cell window attentively, showing alertness to his surroundings.
Stiffens and turns towards the door as footsteps approach, demonstrating situational awareness and readiness.
Pleads and shows distress at having to lead others to harm; tries to find courage but ultimately succumbs to fear and shame.
Requests a little time with the others before an implied terrible event, voice trailing off, showing compassion and care.
Pleads not to lead others, shows refusal and inability to take on difficult responsibility.
Struggles briefly to stand up to Runkel but succumbs, showing lack of courage and confidence.
Attempts to request a little time with the children before the event, showing some presence of mind and initiative.
Composes himself with great effort and throws open the door, preparing to face an ordeal despite fear.
Returns to the children, who greet him with relief and affection; pats their heads comfortingly and reassures them that everything is going to be all right.
Encourages the children to smile and participate in a show despite their lingering fear.
Comforts frightened children, reassures them calmly, organizes them to sit and prepare for a show, checks that all children are accounted for by their names.
Maintains composure despite being emotionally affected, quickly recovers to continue performing his role.
Performs comical tightrope walk and bows, falling on his face to entertain children; children laugh and applaud.
Holds Willie close and fights back tears; Willie kisses Helmut on cheek.
Tries to reassure confused, worried children by fabricating a comforting story about moving buildings and making a circus parade.
Performs an imaginary tightrope walk, recovering comically from near loss of balance, and successfully entertains the children, earning their applause and laughter.
Quickly improvises an explanation to the children's questions about where they are going, attempting to reassure them despite obvious uncertainty and stress.
Fights back tears and displays emotional vulnerability while maintaining his role as entertainer and protector.
Pantomimes playing harmonica to engage the boy and encourage participation.
Leads the children like the Pied Piper, playing music and making them feel secure.
Looks back at the children smiling and waving, trying to maintain their spirits.
Prays silently for a miracle to save the children.
Organizes the children into a line efficiently and finds the boy with the harmonica.
Uses pantomime to communicate effectively with the boy, encouraging participation.
Leads the children confidently at the head of the procession, maintaining their morale and security.
Despite the fearful context, manages to keep the children smiling and moving forward, showing emotional control and leadership.
Internally prays and hopes for a miracle rather than taking direct action to change the dangerous situation.
Gently tousles the hair of little Willie and steers him through the door into the room.
Tries to smile but it is almost grotesque; tries to speak but no words come; shows despair and faltering courage.
Plays the harmonica again as children enter the room.
Reluctantly stands aside and allows children to enter the harsh room, his courage fails him.
Clutches the little girl's hand desperately for comfort and to steady himself despite initial hesitation.
Does not immediately take the girl's hand, showing initial hesitation or distance.
Fights panic silently and controls himself to bring joy to the children by juggling bread and engaging them in laughter.
Does not attempt to open or call for help when door slams behind them, resigning to the situation rather than seeking escape.
Clutches the little girl's hand desperately to steady himself amid panic.
Stops himself from reacting rashly when the door slams shut, controlling his panic.
Uses juggling and lighthearted behavior to calm both himself and the children, transforming tension into gentle laughter.
